comment_text: I forgot to mention in the video why the DNA precipitates. The DNA is not soluble in isopropanol, but it is soluble in water. The isopropanol is miscible with water, so as more is added, the solubility of DNA decreases. If enough is added, the DNA will fall out of solution.

Are you sure that DNA came from strawberries?

PhD Molecular Genetics here. Adding the 2-propanol does indeed result in precipitation of DNA but in this case you are also collecting massive amounts of debris. Ideally you would first break up the strawberrys as much as possible, perhaps by gronding it through a Filter, with this cellular suspension you would then continue. Ideally, wash this with PBS or other buffers to clean up the suspension and transfer the pellet (after centrifugation) to a new container. use a lysis buffer (not a simple hypotonic solution) to burst the pellet of cells and incubate this on ice for roughly 30 minutes. Add Sodium Acetate and alcohol or 2-propanol to the solution and let it sit at -20 for about 2 hours or otherwise overnight. THIS precipitates the DNA but youre not there yet. After incubation, centrifuge the entire suspension at max speed (13000 RPM if it fits in an eppendord) for about an hour to pellet the DNA (+debris). Wash this pellet with 70% ethanol once and let the pellet completely dry. Resuspend this dried pellet of CLEAN dna with water and voila, you got your pure and clean strawberry DNA. Nanodrop to confirm concentration and purity.

Hello, I need to make a correction about what it is said in the beginning of the video about DNA. (I'm a biologist)

The chromosome structure only presents itself when the cells reproduces itself in a process called mitosis or meiosis depending on the type of cell.
The rest of the time the DNA is in a semi-compact structure.

If it was in chromosomes all the time the enzymes would not be able to work on it to produce proteins for example and each cell in our body would die. :)

If I see this correctly, you neither cooled nor stabilized the contents of the cells during/after cell lysis (we use EDTA most of the time). The shown process should have lead to sufficient protein precipitation due to the pH shift... I here assume your soap isn't interacting with the salt like a buffering solution would. As far as I'm aware most dishsoaps these days don't really have that basic character classical soap might provide though, so the solution very probably has no pH buffering properties. This leads to problems when you take a look at DNAs structure and realise how important ionic hydrogen bonds are for it's packed state and how high H+ avaliability would make them fall apart...
But let's keep going. You denaturated your proteins (at least partially) and then filtered a big chunk of them out, but surely not all of them and a bunch of them are enzymes... and even if you actually did filter all of them out, they are your main problem.
The cells have a lot of DNAse and RNAse type enzymes and while you were squishing your plant matter, they already went to work. As long as your temperature is somewhat in their range, they will cut away at any piece of DNA/RNA you exposed, snipping it into fragments at a remarkable speed. The Question that we have to ask ourselves is: what is DNA? Nucleotides are their own category of molecules and short pieces of assembled nucleotides have been observed 'in the wild' so to speak, without being directly linked to life. They just tend to do this thing where they snap together nicely... so you would have to define DNA as such nucleotide containing molecules, with 'sense' information written in their sequence...
But if you let DNA sit out (nucleus destroyed, contents of cell organelles spilled around it) at room temperature in a ion rich environment like that for anything more than 5 Minutes, there will be basically no readable code left. We isolate our nucleotides on ice for a reason and even the centrifuge has to be precooled to near freezing temperatures, to ensure a successful extraction. Most of the time we go so far and freeze our tissues with liquid nitrogen, crush them in that state and add a buffering solution while the tube is still way below freezing point (yes, the solution freezes too, but will start acting as buffer as soon as any mobility returns due to thawing)

I agree you chose a good fruit to work on, since modern strawberries have accumulated lots of DNA during our cultivation (polyploidy isn't all that rare in plants we eat) and their cellular makeup is quite simple + their cell walls are barely deserving of the term 'wall'. That sure made extraction quicker and easier. You also used a lot of fruit - in the lab we tend to use ~10-100 mg (depending on tissue type and plant type) and that yields us a barely visible little flake in the tip of our eppi tubes. And if you are working on a tricky plant with contents that interfere with your protocol, or are to slow or sometimes just... I don't know, sometimes it feels like random cruelty... you still can't isolate anyting of use from your tissues...
I think what you have there isn't really DNA. Is it short sequences of assembled nucleotides, sticking together in the apolarity of the solute? Sure! But is it readable? I really doubt that!

But very nice video that gives people a kind of realistic idea of how modern biology works!
And yes, we have to deal with a lot of chemical randomness, since life throws these crazy complex molecules with funny folding behaviours and functions at us.

All you need to do this is the following: strawberries 1+, water, salt, medical alcohol (such as sanitizer but more liquified), soap, filter (tissue would do), container, stirrer, soap.

Steps: Bash your strawberries real good in a ziploc or in anything. Mix water, then add 1/7 of salt comparing to how much strawberry water you have, mix, next fold your tissue into a cone kind of shape, make sure there arent gaps anywhere. plop some strawberry substance you made into the tissue and squeeze liquid out with your fingers into a container. Next add alcohol (the more the better) and then stir ofc, and then add your soap, stir for 5-7 minutes try to prevent bubbles from forming, if there are any, pop them or try to get rid of them. Next let your container of strawberry substance just stay for 10-15 minutes, you can then see the strawberry dna, its like cobwebs!

In your mixture were not only DNA but also RNA and lots of proteins (mostly proteins to be honest). I did some kind of DNA extraction from bacterial and insect cells. For bacterias I've usually used 0,1M NaOH with 1%SDS as lysis solution which turns cell suspension in slime within few seconds. After this step mixture of phenol, CHCl3 and isoamyl alcohol is used to denaturate all proteins followed by centrifugation. DNA stays in upper water layer while most of the proteins and debris remains in organic layer as solid. pH >7 also results in RNA being quite well hydrolized (which is not an option when you are extracting RNA). Then I've usually added equal parts of ice cold IPA with 3M potassium acetate solution and set whole mix for about an hour at -30C. After this spin tube at about 20k g for 15 minutes and you'll see tiny pellet of DNA which you need to wash with IPA, dry and dissolve into water or Tris buffer with pH of 8,0. This works for plasmid DNA. For genomic DNA no need to add NaOH, just mechanical shear with commercial reagent like Trizol (which smells suspiciously the same as phenol).

The menstrual cycle is a series of natural changes in hormone production and the structures of the uterus and ovaries of the human female reproductive system that make pregnancy possible. Naturally occurring hormones drive two concurrent and coordinated cycles that last about 28 days. The ovarian cycle controls the production and release of eggs and the release of the hormones estrogen and progesterone. The uterine cycle governs the preparation and maintenance of the lining of the uterus (endometrium) to receive a fertilized egg. Menstruation, a "period" in common parlance, begins on day one of the cycle, and lasts for about five days. Around day fourteen, an egg is usually released from the ovary. Estrogen stimulates the uterus lining to thicken to accommodate an embryo should fertilization occur. If implantation does not occur, the lining is released during menstruation. Menarche (the first period) usually occurs around age twelve, and menstrual cycles usually continue for 30–45 years until menopause. Map of countries and territories with current and former Taiwanese diplomatic missions

Taiwan, officially the Republic of China, has 112 diplomatic missions across the world as of December 2020. Due to the One-China policy, other countries are only allowed to maintain relations with either Taiwan or the mainland-based People's Republic of China. As most countries have changed their recognition to the latter over time, only 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic missions have official status, consisting of fifteen embassies and two consulate-generals. Despite these barriers, 57 United Nations members maintain relations with Taiwan on an unofficial basis. To serve these locations and other places throughout the world, 92 semi-official representative offices are utilized for matters that would otherwise be handled by embassies or consulates. Taiwan has established informal representation in China's two special administrative regions as well. In Hong Kong, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Hong Kong provides services similar to a consulate, while relations to Macau are handled by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Macau. I've done this before with students in a lab classroom setting years ago but used calf thymus.  Maybe a bit easier to extract due to the lack of a cell wall.  However probably a bit messier from a biochemical standpoint due to having more proteins and lipids vs strawberries.  I would always add the alcohol slowly to the extraction to form two layers and then stir slowly with a glass rod.  DNA would precipitate at the interface between aqueous and alcohol phases, spooling around the glass rod. Anyway I always thought this was a cool and fun experiment to do with college students

Fun story because I'm bored.
In year 7 (6th grade aka I was 11) we were in a science lesson. My teacher- who I'll call Mr S- was teaching us about organelles and when we came to the nucleus he decided to show off how he could spell deoxyribonucleic acid. I decided to note it down because maybe, in a wild twist of events, I would need that information. However, Mr.S wiped it off the whiteboard before I had finished. I was annoyed, (try telling an 11-year-old autistic child who is obsessed with science that it wasn't a big deal) so I decided to be petty. Mr S- who was bragging about being able to spell deoxyribonucleic acid after years of being a scientist- was about to be outsmarted by an 11-year-old who had less than a year of study on science. That night I spent 10 minutes learning how to spell deoxyribonucleic acid and, after that, I proceeded to think of a theory that, although scientists had already thought of it, was pretty complex for me at the time. This article gives an overview of that, https://www.universetoday.com/118614/is-everything-actually-shrinking/
Needless to say, I impressed Mr S and got 99% on my weekly report.
TLDR: At age 11 I outsmarted my science teacher.

Fun fact: If you hidrolize the long DNA chain into it's nucleotides (Adenin, etc.) they will taste extremely salty and horrible, but if you add them to a salty food in very small proportions, it will turn it's flavor into something delicious, that's because nucleotides have the ability to potencialize salty flavors, in fact, they are used in the food industry to potencialize salty flavors in products like potato chips or intantaneous soups, and it makes them much more delicious that they would be without nucleotides

I cringed when you dumped the isopropanol alcohol in, and I cringed even more when you stirred it. Ach! The isopropanol should not be just dumped in. The beaker with the strained strawberry solution should be tipped slightly and thecold isopropanol should be slowly run down the side of the beaker. I think this is to create a concentration gradient where the majority of the isopropanol stays on top as it is less dense than water. DNA then precipitates out of the solution where it is in contact with the isopropanol and because it is a long chain, it pulls more DNA out of the solution. The dumping and stirring most likely fragmented the DNA as well as precipitating out a lot of contaminants while leaving a considerable amount of DNA dissolved. That is why you had a hard time picking it up with spoon. The DNA was in short bits by then, not long strands.

When pure DNA dries, it loses volume to the point it looks more like a thin white slightly crystalline residue, not a clump. And when DNA becomes extremely dry, it is actually quite difficult to get it to dissolve back into a solution. This means that likely none of what you tasted was DNA, as it was not in your mouth long enough for any to dissolve.

It is also interesting to point out that another reason strawberries are great for this demonstration is that commercial strawberries have an octoploid genome. That means that unlike humans, who have 2 copies of their DNA, or a diploid genome, the strawberry has 8 copies. Polyploid plants are quite often larger than their diploid versions and also have increased plant vigor. Many commercially grown plants are polyploid. Wild strawberries are often diploid, and that is the reason for the size difference from what is bought in store.

After removing the DNA strands with the isopropanol, don't "wad it up" so tightly. Placing it as is on a clean piece of parchment paper, allow it to air dry for at least 24 hours, more if you live in a damper climate. Remove the dried DNA and brush lightly with egg white. Dust it with 10x powdered sugar and toast very quickly just to start the sugar browning. Finally, remove the result and throw it away.

Hahaha. I've extracted a lot of DNA and RNA using similar methods for research purposes, and I've often wondered what it tasted like. After all, the flavors of the other big macromolecules are common enough. Some things: Using cold isopropanol is an old method -- thought to be essential -- but is now discouraged as it strongly increases co-precipitation of salts (although a lot of people still insist on using cold methods). Your DNA would probably be a lot less salty if you had just used room temp stuff. And saying DNA strands pair by hydrogen bonding isn't really right -- they could hydrogen bond with the water molecules just as easily. The hydrogen bonds are required, but the driving force is the hydrophobic effect from the nonpolar components of the nucleotides. Just oil and water not mixing.

Most of what precipitates this way are DNA associated proteins, RNA, and salt. I would expect that only 1-2% of that pellet is actually DNA.

To get pure DNA, you would have to do neutral phenol chloroform extraction and then precipitate the DNA from the aqueous layer with isopropanol or ethanol in the presence of salt (to neutralize the phosphate-sugar backbone). Pellet the DNA by centrifugation which yields a white pellet. The white colour is given by the salt which is washed off with 70% ethanol. This leaves pure DNA which is colourless but has a UV absorbance peak around 260nm. (RNA will also coprecipitate with the DNA, but removing this requires treatment with a ribonuclease.)

Hey Nile,
You're probably not going to read this but I'd like make a few remarks on your intro where you explain DNA and its structure.
First of, you state that only one strand is used to store the information (genes) and the other is merely a backup for DNA repair. This is however not true, genes can be read from either strand depending on their orientation. The orientation is determined as DNA is always read from 5' to 3' refering to the positions on the deoxyribose in combination with other factors. These other factors are things like promoter and terminater sequences, the methionine codon which indicates the start of the gene and other regulatory sequences (inhibitors and enhancers).
The other misconception is that DNA is always stored in the form of tightly packed chromosomes, this only occurs during mitosis, if DNA was consistently packed like this there would be no space for mRNA to be synthesised. DNA is stored in the cell as chromatin fibers which are, indeed, wrapped around histones in some places, but free in others. This is part of a field we are just now beginning to understand called epigenetics. By having some parts of our DNA wrapped and inaccesible to RNA polymerase the sets of genes that can be transcribed differ from cell to cell, this is in addition to other epigenetic features such as DNA methylation, histone acetylation/methylation and others. This is why skin cells won't produce, for example, insulin while liver cells can despite sharing the same genome.

Anyway, my apologies if I come over as the guy you want to avoid at parties ;)
I love the content you're putting out there and I hope you can keep creating the videos you want to.

My sincerest regards,

Technically speaking, the human tonge does not have any DNA receptors of taste. It has only five diferent receptors: for sweetness (activated on sugars), sourness (activated on H+), saltiness (activated on Na+) , bitterness (activated on various bittering agents), and umami (activated on monosodium glutamate). That's why you tasted only saltiness, becouse there was sodium in the mixture. So DNA has no taste at all. But that was a realy nice video.

In fact, a major reason that mucus in your body is so thick and slimy is because of genomic DNA from broken down cells. When a fellow biology grad student told me that a while ago, I didn't really believe him until I looked it up for myself. Apparently, recombinant DNases (enzymes which break down DNA) for inhalation were patented to treat patients with cystic fribrosis to loosen up the mucus in their airways. No idea on what the efficacy was like, my guess there are much better and cheaper ways to clear their lungs, but the fact that it worked at all really shows how these gross physical properties of boogers and snot is primarily conferred by the DNA itself, and really hammers home how these things we think of in very abstract and detached ways we can actually are very familiar with, even if we don't know it.

if you had used frozen/thawed strawberries, they would have been cheaper than fresh, easier to squish, and easier to extract from, since freezing would break the cell walls more consistently than just crushing them with your hands. and you didn't explain the most interesting reason why strawberries are good for DNA extraction: due to selective breeding, they tend to have more than 2 copies of each chromosome (some varieties have up to 8 copies), meaning they literally, physically have more DNA per cell than many alternatives.

It definitely would've been a good idea to edute the salt off of the DNA before tasting, probably by doing a few washing steps with water. Since humans have evolved tastes based on what chemicals the body needs, things like fats, carbohydrates and sugars often have intense flavors. Contrary to this, only very minute amounts of nucleic acids are necessary in our diet, both because we can synthesize it ourselves and literally any food produced from an organism will contain some, so you are more likely to lack a different macromolecule in the first place, meaning it wouldn't be likely for humans to develop a taste specifically for DNA. As such, I would expect it to be essentially flavorless (perhaps a little umami flavor if some contaminating proteins stayed bound to the DNA).

I'm currently using a DNA kit from Quiagen for extraction, and it looks a lot like what you're doing in here. One of the reagents gets very sudsy if I shook the bottle too much, which now I realize it could have been some sort of soap. We warm the sample overnight with that reagent and some protease, in order to break up the proteins and release the DNA. I imagine if you warmed your sample as well, you could have extracted even more DNA. Given your starting sample size of 10 strawberries, that's probably not gonna make a significant difference. The washing buffer also requires addition of 100% pure alcohol; the rest I imagine are probably some chemicals to stabilize the DNA. So all in all pretty similar stuff.

The video also reminds me of phenol-chloroform extraction I used to do on cancer tumor samples. I used Trizol (which is a pretty nasty reagent that breaks up proteins) to dissolve the samples, and then used phenol and chloroform to help precipitate out the DNA. You probably wouldn't want to eat the extracted DNA after that, though.

Given how long DNA is, I think it was probably a bad idea to use a coffee filter. DNA may be a molecule, but it's super long (especially when tangled with other molecules), so I'm pretty sure you filtered out most of the DNA you had collected.
When I've done DNA extraction labs for undergraduates, we always just used cheesecloth to filter out the big bits of strawberry. We also didn't pour the alcohol like that, we gently poured it on the side of the glass to make two distinct layers. That seems to work quite well, and you get a shockingly large amount of DNA from even just one small strawberry. I would have expected you to get a LOT more DNA based on the number of strawberries you used.
